user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimeBaseGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_TimeBaseGetInfo(osal_id_t timebase_id, OS_timebase_prop_t *timebase_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *           record;
    int32                          return_code;
    osal_objtype_t                 objtype;
    OS_object_token_t              token;
    OS_timebase_internal_record_t *timebase;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(timebase_prop);

    /*
     * Check our context.  Not allowed to use the timer API from a timer callback.
     * Just interested in the object type returned.
     */
    objtype = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(OS_TaskGetId_Impl());
    if (objtype == OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE)
    {
        return OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
    }

    memset(timebase_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_timebase_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, timebase_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_timebase_table, token);
        timebase = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timebase_table, token);

        strncpy(timebase_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(timebase_prop->name) - 1);
        timebase_prop->creator               = record->creator;
        timebase_prop->nominal_interval_time = timebase->nominal_interval_time;
        timebase_prop->freerun_time          = timebase->freerun_time;
        timebase_prop->accuracy              = timebase->accuracy_usec;

        return_code = OS_TimeBaseGetInfo_Impl(&token, timebase_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TimeBaseGetInfo:
osal_id_t OS_TaskGetId_Impl(void)
{
    OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t self_record;

    /* cppcheck-suppress unreadVariable // intentional use of other union member */
    self_record.opaque_arg = pthread_getspecific(POSIX_GlobalVars.ThreadKey);

    return self_record.id;
}
...
static inline osal_objtype_t OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(osal_id_t id)
{
    return (OS_ObjectIdToInteger(id) >> OS_OBJECT_TYPE_SHIFT);
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE 0x08
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_timebase_table
...
OS_timebase_internal_record_t OS_timebase_table[OS_MAX_TIMEBASES]
...
int32 OS_TimeBaseGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_timebase_prop_t *timer_prop)
{
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I have reported the two places that require investigation for possible unreachable code:
- The check of the current context object type (objtype == OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE) and the immediate return. This depends on the value returned by OS_TaskGetId_Impl() and how object IDs are encoded; if a task context can never encode a timebase type, this branch would be unreachable.
- The entire success branch after OS_ObjectIdGetById(...). Whether this branch can ever be taken depends on the semantics/encoding used by OS_ObjectIdGetById and the id parameter (LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE vs the actual timebase id encoding). If the combination of id arguments and token conversion cannot succeed for timebase IDs, the whole block would be unreachable.

Other code fragments were not reported because they are ordinary, directly reachable operations or simple definitions that do not, by themselves, imply unreachable code:
- The parameter check macro (OS_CHECK_POINTER), the memset(timebase_prop,...), and the final return(return_code) are standard and reachable depending on the prior control flow.
- The local variable declarations, the OS_TimeBaseGetInfo_Impl() implementation (which here returns OS_SUCCESS), the OS_ObjectIdGetById implementation skeleton, and simple macros/constants do not themselves show impossible-to-reach paths without further semantic information about ID encodings and transaction functions. Investigation should therefore focus on the two reported fragments and the ID/type encoding and transaction routines they depend on to determine if any branch is truly unreachable.
